captions.text:
What up B? This week on Thug Notes
we flying solo With Jane Eyre by Charlotte Bronte.

As a kid, Jane Eyre livin with her
twisted aunt Ms. Reed and her punk ass cousins

who ain’t showin no love for my girl Jane.
After dealin with these haters fo years, some

righteous doc named Lloyd hooks Jane up, and
convinces Ms. Reed to send Jane away to get

schooled. But Jane ain’t bout to bounce
before giving Ms. Reed a big ol’ fu** YOU.

So Jane arrives at Lowood school
where some bitch-ass clergyman named Brocklehurst

starts hatin on my girl saying she ain’t
nothing but a lying trick. But Jane’s homie

Helen and a righteous teach names Miss Temple
tell Jane they got her back. When Jane’s

sistah Helen dies from consumption and Miss
Temple chunks deuce outta Lowood, Jane bails

and start hustlin as a governess up in Thornfield
hall, some uptown gangsta named Edward Rochester
be livin.

Once Jane meets Eddie, they start
chillin on the reg. But meanwhile, some mysterious

sh** starts going down at Thornfield: crazy
laughing, somebody starting a fire in Eddie’s
room, and one of the house guests gettin shanked.

Later, crusty aunt Reed sends the
word that she bout to kick the bucket. Jane’s

forgiveness don’t quit so she go back home
and nurses this ho.

When Jane rolls back to Thornfield,
Edward proposes and they plan on shackin up

together. sh** gets ridiculous during the
ceremony when some playa hater named Mason

say that Edward is already married. Seems
Edward’s wife, Bertha, went whack in the

head and she the one who been wreckin sh**
in Eddie’s crib.

Jane be straight trippin about
Edward actin like a pimp and peaces out of
Thornfield.

Jane be all cashed out askin for
help til some playas named Rivers take her

in- turns out they be her cousins! And when
Jane’s Uncle John dies, he leaves her some
mad cash! Now Jane got c-notes by the stack.

Then Jane starts jonesing for her
boy Edward, so she drops in on Thornfield

and sees that the whole place has been burnt
down! Turns out, Bertha’s twisted ass dun

blazed the whole place then killed herself.
DAMN! Not only that, but Eddie dun lost his

sight and his hand during the scuffle. But
Jane keeps it real and says, “Hey blood,

I don’t care how ugly you is, I love you
anyway.” Then they get married and even
have a little G of they own.

Aight son, if you a hustla,
you

know that the cribs where Jane been stayin
at symbolize all the bullsh** women had to

deal with in Victorian patriarchal society:
Opression wit auntie reed, starvation at Lowood,

madness at Thornfield, and indifference when
kickin it with the Rivers. But it ain’t

til we hear bout Eddie’s crazy biddy Bertha,
that Bronte starts doin it big.

So if you forever thuggin, you
gotta check how Bronte makin Bertha Jane’s

shadow double, play boy. All the slangin and
bangin that this hoochie be doin up in Eddie’s

turf representin all that rage Jane been keepin
inside since her days with Auntie Reed. In

fact, it don’t get no realer than Bertha
since she the only one fightin the power that

dun fu**ed her over. Cuz on the real, who
wouldn’t wanna start tearin sh** up if you
got sold to some stranger for a bit o cash?

So what my girl Charlotte tryna say
bout traditional society is: why can’t women
express they desires without bein called crazy?

Yo. You best get in da zone and
listen to this here motif, blood. Bronte be

stackin images of nature to show how Jane’s
amped up emotions go beyond what’s acceptable

for women to be feeling. For example, when
Rochester proposes to Jane, it starts storming

all up in there fo 2 straight hours. It’s
like her joy is as intense as the storm itself.

And since she been keepin it in for so long,
sh** goes wild when she finally able to let
it out.

You can check how Bronte extends
this nature motif to my boy Eddie too. After

he proposes to Jane, lighting strikes a big
ass tree, splitting it in half. The two halves

of the tree representin Eddie’s divided
loyalties- one to his passion for Jane, the

other for to the law and the church who ain’t
got no love for they union.

Bronte also
spittin truth bout the state of the Victorian

woman through the red room Jane gets locked
up in. This room full of secret compartments

and bloody images, which be associated wit
dat oohie! So dat red room really be all

the isolation and hating that women gotta
deal with during they development in to adulthood.
Ya heard?

Yo thanks for chillin wit yo boy
Sparky. Hit subscribe and see yo ass next week!

title: Jane Eyre - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.text:
This Sparky character really is doing a very good service to students by 
explaining and summarizing the book in a very expressive and educational 
way, by using metaphors and language expressions that the young can 
associate with he is making it easy to take in and learn. This person in my 
opinion deserves respect and admiration for his efforts.﻿

comments.text: +pollytheparrot46 these rock. Comedy g!
comments.author: nosuchthing8

comments.text:
Well, I was in the same mentality when I was in school. It's hard to get 
into something that you have been assigned to, no doubt. But as I grew 
older I start to appreciate a lot of things which I wouldn't touch in the 
past, literature being one of those things. I actually finished Jane Eyre 
after quitting the class even though there was no obligation anymore, and 
came here to see what Sparky has to say about it, mostly for 
self-entertainment and recommendations (with other works I haven't read). I 
see a lot of people asking for analysis of their favorite books on this 
channel, which means they have read it, haven't they?
But hey, it's just my story. If I have anything to say, it would be try to 
enjoy it while you have to deal with it.
comments.author: Thanh Pham

comments.text:
But, see I'd consider that having been assigned for a class. People read 
Jane Eyre without it being assigned. But do they come here and watch the 
video? Probably not. Who needs a summary whey you don't have a test?
comments.author: pollytheparrot46

comments.text:
Me, Me. Although I started reading this as part of an online class I 
partook in, I continued reading this even after quitting the class. My man 
Sparky dropped some hard truths with his rhymes, but in my opinion it's 
only about 70% of the book. I encourage you to read it if you haven't, for 
this is truly a masterpiece.

comments.author: Jordan Benjamin

comments.text:
I loved the book "Jane Eyre". It demonstrated how women struggled but 
learned to be independent. Jane had a horrible child-hood but still kept 
moving forward. The way Jane was treated symbolizes how society mistreated 
lower class women. Women were seen  inferior to men and women could not do 
anything about it. So this is the reason why Jane finally went off and 
showed so much emotions towards everything and everyone because she no 
longer wanted to feel inferior to anyone. I give props to Jane for standing 
up for her self.﻿
comments.author: Erandy Lopez

comments.text:
Personally Jane Eyre is my favorite book because I love how Bronte 
describesthe oppression the Victorian women went through. In those times 
they were expected to marry at a young age and raise a family and if not 
then they would become a governess. Either way theyd end up unhappy and 
dependent. The book showed how Bronte wanted to be independent and able to 
express what she felt so she did it through the character Jane and her foil 
Bertha. Bertha may have been insane but it symbolized how women in the 
victorian era felt inside.﻿
comments.author: Denise Garcia

comments.text:
Jane directly represented the problems the victorian woman went through. in 
jane eyre many objects symbolized and foreshadowed events, I agree with the 
red room symbolizing womans oppression, and i believe the split tree 
foreshadowed their future as a couple ﻿
comments.author: Samuel Zarate

comments.text:
I didn't think the tree meant that, I personally believe it stood for Jane 
and his doomed marriage as it happened at the tree where he proposed but 
other than that spot on with the analysis!﻿
comments.author: Luis Tirado

comments.text:
I found it interesting how all the mess Bertha creates are the inner 
feelings Jane holds within her. When I read the novel I just thought Bertha 
was just some random crazy character but with the analyzes it all makes 
sense. Jane was put through so much while growing up, by her aunt and her 
being an orphan, but she never released her inner emotions she always held 
it in and well Bertha she was Bertha.﻿
comments.author: Salvador Reyes

comments.text: The red room scene finally makes sense to me :D haha﻿
comments.author: Sheyla Cervantes

comments.text:
The idea of the tree being split in half representing the two sides of 
Rochester's loyalties is a great way to look at things. When i first read 
this part i thought it would have been the good and bad to come if 
Rochester and Jane were to get married. Through the compromise of the good 
and bad Jane would have chose whether to marry Rochester or not. ﻿
comments.author: Monse G

comments.text:
I really thought that the idea of the split tree in Bronte's "Jane Eyre" to 
be quite interesting. How Jane was split in her decision of whether to 
follow laws, or to break Victorian woman rules and follow her heart with 
Rochester. Also, the tone in which she would describe all these mysterious 
scenes with Bertha. Her word choices are what made this story so popular 
for her, as well as the choice to not reveal Bertha until almost the end.﻿
comments.author: EstherMalicious

comments.text:
I agree with the thought that Jane represent the Victorian women of her 
time as well as their issues that they had to go through to mold themselves 
into the image society wanted.﻿
comments.author: Itzel Ortiz

comments.text:
In this interpretation of Jane Eyre I believe most of what was said is 
accurate. However I do not believe that the bad weather when Rochester 
proposes to Jane symbolizes all the emotions that Jane has been keeping in. 
In my opinion the bad weather symbolizes how it was a wrong move and how 
the future for Jane and Rochester will not be good. To add on I do agree 
that Bronte used this novel to show how women were to act but Jane was 
represented as the opposite and did everything that most women were not 
expected to do in many ways. ﻿
comments.author: andrea valverde

comments.text:
This video is funny. I like how the vocabulary is modern and easy to 
understand. I especially liked the analysis part of the video. I thought it 
was interesting how everything in Jane's life represented the difficulties 
women in the Victorian era faced. I also liked the fact that Bertha is the 
double for Jane because Bertha lets go and goes crazy, but it thought that 
Blanche Ingram was a double for Jane. ﻿
comments.author: MariaElena Ybarra

comments.text:
When it comes to the tree being split by the lightning, I don’t agree that 
it represented Rochester’s divided loyalty. I feel as if it’s way more than 
that. The storm after his proposal represents the overall divine 
disapproval of the marriage itself. Rochester's secrets will split up their 
marriage, just the way the lightning split the tree. The tree is almost an 
omen to predict the transformations that will occur with Jane and 
Rochester, and since the tree is not divided at the roots, it also 
indicates their eventual union. Rochester just can’t be himself without 
Jane, and he’ll never recover completely from the trauma of their 
separation, just like the tree will never be the same after getting struck 
by lightning.  Not only that, but the bond at the base of the tree, to me, 
represented hope; hope in the sense that they will still be together as 
one, even though they are broken.﻿
comments.author: Viviana Lira

comments.text:
I agree how he says Bronte is trying to show why when women try to express 
there ideas or emotions they have to get all crazy or people think they are 
crazy during this time period. I also agree how anytime Jane mood changes 
the weather changes along with it. But I don't see how the Red Room Jane 
was locked in is related to a women's private area. ﻿
comments.author: Joe Lopez II

comments.text:
I really liked how he described Jane as being the Victorian woman back 
then, they didn't really have much say in anything but to follow the 
husbands duties. I also agree that the red room is very symbolic because it 
represents isolation that woman had to deal with during development to 
adulthood. Also how Jane would always keep her feelings to herself because 
she had no say in things but then after she found out about Mr. Rochester 
she let out all her feelings.﻿
comments.author: Jazmine Zavalza

comments.text:
I disagree with the idea that Bertha is Jane's double because Jane does not 
have that much rage about her past because then she wouldn't have gone 
back. Jane is educated and wants to fit in the Victorian society since she 
wanted to be like Mrs. Ingram. I like the argument he makes on how the 
split tree represents Jane and the other half the law/society. ﻿
comments.author: Denise Flores

comments.text:
I think Mr. Rochester would be the man feminist would hate in the open and 
talk bad about, but then in the private want his love more than anything. 
kinda like Jane. I thought he brought the story all together.﻿
comments.author: falloutjustcause

comments.text:
I disagree on the idea that Berta is a reflection of Jane. Bertha is a 
example of pure insanity of having lost her mind while being with mr. 
Rochester, while Jane is sane and has no anger built up in her system just 
her feelings and thoughts of people in her surrounding Environment. I also 
disagree on the point that the tree splitting symbolizes Mr. Rochesters 
locality to Jane and the church I think it symbolizes his commitment to 
both jane his new wife and old insane wife Berta.﻿
comments.author: Rakayla Simpson

comments.text:
Jane eyre was such a great novel, when Helen died it had me in tears. I 
completely agree with the question he asks saying why can't women do what 
they please without getting called crazy. Jane does follow the Victorian 
women ideology and I love her character I don't find anything wrong with 
that. However i hate how Bertha was portrayed in the book. I pictured her 
horrifying but when I did analysis I realized she was just like any sane 
person, being locked in the room changed her. Her being portrayed as 
"crazy" is silly considering she was mentally abused and mistreated locked 
in a room for all these years. ﻿
comments.author: Kimberly Uribe

comments.text: Tess of the d'Urbervilles by Scott Elledge﻿
comments.author: J1P2K

comments.text:
This video made me really get Jane Eyre. Before seeing this i didn't really 
get every bit of it or why somethings were added . I liked how he described 
what woman had to deal with in the Victorian society and how Brontë showed 
Bertha as a mad woman to show that women couldn't express their feelings 
with out being called crazy . Also i didn't know that Bertha was basically 
a shadow to Jane, all the rage that Jane had inside was shown by Berthas 
actions . The definition of the red room amazed me !﻿
comments.author: zaira morales

comments.text:
Correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe the chestnut tree that was split in 
half by lightning was connected by the roots, representing their 
temporarily split relationship that still has roots deep enough to sustain 
it, which is most likely why they end up getting back together again; as 
long as the roots still live, the tree can always come back to life again. 
Just wanted to add that in there, since I think that's a pretty important 
part that came up.﻿
comments.author: AquaSushiX3

comments.text:
+brenda casillas A spark of love -- ? We're told that they continue to have 
a deep, passionate love they both feel intensely throughput the "breakup" 
scene in chap. 27
comments.author: Timothy Johnson

comments.text:
I agree with you , Since they still had a spark of love deep down in them 
all this fire was what caused both of them to get back together, Jane 
visiting Rochester made her true feelings come out same for him bring them 
together,
What heppen to the tree and the lighting was somthing ironic that happened. 
it was overall ironic how at first Jane was poor and alone and at the end 
Rochester was alone .
comments.author: brenda casillas

comments.text:
I liked how he explained that Jane represented Victorian woman and how they 
didn't get to express how they felt about the situation. They always had to 
follow what the men would tell them and they way she suffered. Also the 
nature would reflect back on how Jane was feeling or when the storm 
happened that something bad was going to happen after he proposed to her.﻿
comments.author: Alexis Martinez

comments.text:
I really liked how he included the different motifs, for example, the 
storms he talked about. The storms made Bronte's audience realize that 
things weren't all that great as they seemed to be. Every time the audience 
thought something good was going to happen it was soon knocked out with an 
bad outcome. And the reoccurring image of thunder made us as readers 
predict that something fatal was going to happen. I really enjoy watching 
these videos, because as readers we should be able to see different 
perspectives and not only stick to one. ﻿
comments.author: Beatriz Gonzalez

comments.text:
i agree that the red room can be represented as all the isolation and hate 
that women had to go through during their development to adulthood. that 
can be one example of an aspect of Ambiguity in the story that Jane goes 
through. ﻿
comments.author: ariana corona

comments.text:
The question he says Bronte is asking through berthas actions, “Why can’t 
woman express their desires without getting called crazy?” makes sense. She 
was sold to a stranger for some money and that guy locked her up and found 
someone new. As a woman at that time, she could have been considered crazy 
just because she did not fit in with the expectations society asked for. 
For example, Jane was mistreated, bullied, and judged just because she was 
an orphan who’s features were plain but she did nothing to defend herself 
until she got money and a husband and moved up in society. Bertha, on the 
other hand, did something to get her revenge for not being loved by her 
family nor husband just because society didn’t allow them too.﻿
comments.author: Alondra Vazquez

comments.text:
This video helped me understand the story more then before. It showed that 
Jane represented the ideal Victorian women and how it was hard for women to 
express how they really felt.﻿
comments.author: Jorge Mondragon

comments.text:
The symbolism behind Bertha's craziness is that in many cases the 
oppression of society made women go mad because they couldn't express them 
selves  ﻿
comments.author: leticia castro

comments.text:
This video helped my understanding to the book. Charlotte Bronte in her 
novel wants the reader to understand that Jane is an idea women during the 
Victorian Era. I found the summary and analysis very helpful but he should 
have gone more in depth with the fire scene in Thorfield. ﻿

comments.text:
This video helped refresh my memory, everything was well explained. I like 
how he said that Jane represents Victorian Women. She perfectly represents 
Victorian Women by the way she suffers throughout the book. A perfect 
example of Victorian Women is when Jane leaves Thornfield, she has no 
shelter neither food.﻿

comments.text:
I love this book and tall the symbolism and the view it gives us of the 
past. Jane throughout the novel gives us an idea of the thing women of the 
time had to do and were expected to be. I also like the many topic that 
Charlotte Bronte gets to from loneliness, hatred, and love at the end. Thug 
Notes always gives a fresh prospective on the some classical literature and 
the analyzes always brings up new points﻿

comments.text: This is brilliant.﻿

through visuals and humor. I found both the summary and the analysis really

comments.text:
The part that I enjoyed the most was where he said that Jane represented

Bronte disliked that woman could not express the way that they felt. Woman

comments.author: ProudDiabetic93Again

comments.text:
Charlotte Bronte was a proto-feminist who whined that women were forced to 
make puddings and knit stockings and raise kids. She wanted to be free to 
do the things that the men in her society did. (As long as those men were 
of a high economic status. If she had been asked to do the things that the 
miserable, poor low-class men who made up most of society routinely 
did--like spend 16 hour days working in mines or on farms, or dying in the 
muck of a battlefield, I'm sure she would have changed her tune quickly!)﻿
comments.author: theproplady

comments.text:
actually feminism is a movement that also criticises economic inequality 
and control of economic institutions and oppression of the lower poorer 
classes,which makes it a movement that also benefits men. unfortunately it 
is misinterpreted by many who do not see the link between income inequality 
+ women's rights issues. Although Jane Eyre is a novel that does not really 
explore the plight of poor working class men,it doesnt mean that the 
movement as a whole doesnt care about poverty.
comments.author: lonely lemonade

comments.text:
Yeah, Jane Austin is all about that too. Wisecrack's "Pride and prejudice" 
analysis actually points that out too- the traditional vs. the "empowered".
comments.author: Brankica

comments.text:
I haven't read the book myself, but Sparky suggested that the message was 
about women's freedom of expression 3:14
A lot of internet dwellers are afraid of the feminist bogeyman but 
Charlotte Bronte's ideas seem more complex than what you're suggesting.
